step_1.description: Take the steak out of the fridge 10-15 minutes early.

step_3.description: Let the steak come to room temperature.

step_4.description: Prepare the chimichurri sauce: chop the shallot, roll the herbs, and season with salt, pepper, and garlic.

step_6.description: Prepare the mashed potatoes with grated goat cheese.

step_1.description: Heat the pan until piping hot.

step_2.description: Sear the steak by adding oil, garlic, and thyme.

step_3.description: Flip the steak when necessary and add more seasoning.

step_4.description: Add butter and baste the steak.

step_5.description: Allow the steak to rest and caramelize.

step_1.description: Place the mashed potatoes on the serving canvas.

step_2.description: Make a well in the mashed potatoes.

step_3.description: Add the chimichurri to the well.

step_4.description: Roll the steak in its resting juices.

step_5.description: Slice the steak across the grain.

step_6.description: Place the sliced steak on top of the mashed potatoes.

step_7.description: Drizzle the remaining chimichurri over the steak.

step_1.description: Preheat a pan and let the steak come to room temperature.

step_2.description: Season the steak generously and let it sit for 20 minutes.

step_3.description: Sear the steak in a hot pan, focusing on the fat and bone.

step_4.description: Add garlic and fresh herbs to enhance the flavor.

step_5.description: Flip the steak when necessary and continue searing until crispy.

step_6.description: Add butter and baste the steak while it rests.

step_7.description: Prepare chimichurri sauce with shallots, mint, cilantro, and oregano.

step_8.description: Season the sauce with salt, pepper, garlic, and smoked paprika.

step_9.description: Drizzle with extra virgin olive oil and lemon juice.

step_10.description: Serve the steak with mashed potatoes and a generous amount of chimichurri.

difficulty.reason: This recipe is moderate in difficulty due to the need for specific techniques such as searing the steak and preparing the chimichurri sauce. It requires some knowledge of cooking times and temperatures, as well as the ability to multitask during the cooking process. The recipe also involves using some ingredients that may not be commonly found in every kitchen, such as fresh mint, cilantro, and oregano, along with a specific cut of steak. However, the recipe is not overly complex and can be followed by someone with intermediate cooking skills.

transcript: There's nothing better than a perfectly cooked seared steak. So today, I'm going to show you how to get the perfect sear on a steak and top it off with a delicious chimichurri served with mashed potato. First off, get the pan piping hot. As you wait for that to get up to temperature, make sure your steak, I've got a bone-in rib eye, make sure that's out of the fridge at least 10-15 minutes early. While you're waiting for that, a really nice season. Now, be generous in the season because we lose 30% of the seasoning, especially in the searing. So, I like to get this out literally 20 minutes before I use it. Sear the fat, the bone, and sort of press all that seasoning into it. Once that steak's up to temp, now I've got the heat in my pan, I can turn down the gas and start that beautiful sear. Not too crazy on the oil. In, roll it around the seasoning and always lay away. Always lay away from me. That way we don't splash or burn ourselves. The steak has got up to room temperature and that caramelization takes place really fast. Turn the gas down. I've got the heat in the pan already, as you can see. In there, I'm going to add a little touch of garlic. Again, I don't even have to peel that garlic, just in. Half. Now, the secret here is to be patient. Don't turn that steak until you need to turn it. I've got some fresh thyme in there to make it really nice and aromatic. And be generous with those herbs because all we do now is imparting that amazing flavor. So, check this out. Turn that over and look at that sear. That crust is beautiful. Now we sear the other side. The temperature of that meat is still quite cold, so when you turn it over, always just turn the gas up a little bit to make sure we concentrate on that beautiful sear. Use your tongs and push down. Take advantage of that beautiful base, that incredible nonstick. And more importantly, the heat that's been conducted in the pan. It is so important, especially the sear. And that helps differentiate between boiling a steak and searing a steak. Look at the crust on that already. Once that has beautifully seared on the top, I go back again and just lightly season that. Fresh salt, fresh pepper. And now, a little touch more oil, just a touch on the top. I'm going to sear the back of that steak now. Use the side of the pan to help tilt the pan. And I'll sear the back of that steak. That's really important. And those bevelled parts of this beautiful pan is perfect for the circumference of that amazing rib eye. Now look, my garlic is roasting. Now I'll go into the butter. And this is where you make too many mistakes when the butter goes in too early. And more importantly, it starts to burn. I'm going to turn down the gas now. OK, because I've got the heat in the pan. Pan's worked its magic. Gas goes down. And all we'll do now is add the butter and baste that beautiful steak. Tilt the pan down and baste. Baste, baste, baste. I'm going to sit it there, turn the gas right down. OK, and just let it geously caramelise and get that nice sear. That is so important. Let that rest. Turn the gas off. And then just literally every two or three minutes, baste it again. Just baste. Nothing more, just baste. And so as that sits, it's absorbing all that flavour. And more importantly, it's relaxing in that beautiful heated pan. Right, chimichurri. Very simple. Start off with a shallot. And this is a really nice rustic sauce. It's a beautiful sort of wake-up for that nice, rich, incredible, intense flavour. I'm using a shallot. It's a lot sweeter. Red onion is perfect for this as well. I don't like to get the sort of, the too harsh of an onion flavour. I want a really nice, sweet shallot. It's sort of a really nice sauce. In with the shallots. Take your bowl to the shallots. In they go. Now, the base of this chimichurri, I've got some fresh mint. I've got some cilantro. And I've got some beautiful oregano. And roll them up like you're rolling a big cigar. And just nip it together. Okay, now, I like to slice my herbs once. If we chop them too fine, all the goodness comes out and bleeds on the board. So I go through them with a knife once. Into my bowl. And the fragrance sits in the chimichurri. But look at my board. You can see how dry my board is. When you over chop herbs on a board, all of a sudden the goodness is on the board. And I want the goodness inside this chimichurri. From there, a nice season of salt, pepper, and then the garlic. I don't want big shards of garlic, so take a microplane and just grate that garlic. And what that does, you can see it just almost purees that garlic. That's what I want. My garlic puree. Take a spoon, take that off, and put that in. So that sort of disintegrates and moves away. And literally hides a little touch of smoked paprika. A little touch of red wine vinegar. And then my extra virgin olive oil. Okay, that goes in. Let that mix up. Now, we don't want this too oily. Okay, remember, the ribeye steak, it's rich, it's sumptuous. It's everything you want from a steak. Now, mix that together. And then correct the seasoning. And finish that, finally, with a nice squeeze of lemon juice. That brings that steak and just literally lifts it up. Extra virgin olive oil on top of those herbs. And now those herbs are bleeding.
